avalancheActivity.comment:
The new snow of the last few days is poorly bonded with the old snowpack. The fresh snow as well as the scattered wind slabs can be released in some cases at intermediate and high altitudes. This applies in particular on steep slopes, and in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain.
Avalanches can also be released in the old snowpack and reach medium size in particular on steep shady slopes.
The avalanche prone locations are difficult to recognise.
avalancheActivity.highlights: The new snow of the last few days is in some cases still prone to triggering. Weak layers in the old snowpack can still be released by people.

snowpackStructure.comment:
15 to 25 cm of snow has fallen since Saturday above approximately 1800 m. Towards its surface, the snowpack is moist, in particular below approximately 2100 m. The new snow of the last few days is poorly bonded with the old snowpack.
Towards its base, the snowpack is faceted. This applies in particular on steep east, north and west facing slopes,.

tendency.highlights: Some snow will fall in particular in the regions exposed to the foehn wind. The wind will be moderate to strong. Slight increase in avalanche danger.

avalancheActivity.comment:
Avalanches can be released in deeper layers, in particular by large additional loads. These can reach medium size. Weak layers in the old snowpack are difficult to recognise.
At low and intermediate altitudes thus far only a little snow is lying. Watch out for the numerous rocks hidden by the little recent snow.
avalancheActivity.highlights: Isolated avalanche prone weak layers exist in the old snowpack. Weak layers in the old snowpack are difficult to recognise.

snowpackStructure.comment:
2 to 5 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen since Tuesday above approximately 1800 m. Towards its surface, the snowpack is moist, in particular below approximately 2100 m.
In some places new snow is lying on a hard crust.
At low altitude less snow than usual is lying. Watch out for the numerous rocks hidden by the little recent snow.

avalancheActivity.comment:
Above approximately 1800 m snow has fallen since Tuesday. The fresh snow as well as the scattered wind slabs can be released in some cases at intermediate and high altitudes. This applies in particular on steep slopes, and in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain.
Weak layers in the old snowpack can be released especially by large additional loads. Avalanches can also be released in the old snowpack and reach medium size in particular on steep shady slopes. Weak layers in the old snowpack are treacherous.
avalancheActivity.highlights: Some snow has fallen since Tuesday. Weak layers in the old snowpack are treacherous.

snowpackStructure.comment:
10 to 15 cm of snow has fallen since Tuesday above approximately 2000 m. Towards its surface, the snowpack is moist, in particular below approximately 2100 m. The new snow of the last few days is poorly bonded with the old snowpack, in particular on steep slopes, and in gullies and bowls in particular at intermediate and high altitudes.
Towards its base, the snowpack is faceted. This applies in particular on steep east, north and west facing slopes,.

tendency.highlights: Some snow will fall in particular in the regions exposed to the foehn wind. The wind will be moderate to strong. Slight increase in avalanche danger.

avalancheActivity.comment:
In some places new snow is lying on the smooth surface of an old snowpack.
Avalanches can as before be released by large loads, but they will be small in most cases.
The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular in gullies and bowls above approximately 2200 m and at transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack.
Watch out for the numerous rocks hidden by the little recent snow.
avalancheActivity.highlights: Individual avalanche prone locations for dry avalanches are to be found in particular on very steep slopes above approximately 2200 m.

snowpackStructure.comment:
2 to 5 cm of snow has fallen since Tuesday above approximately 2000 m. Over a wide area new snow and wind slabs are lying on a hard crust.
Towards its surface, the snowpack is moist, in particular below approximately 2100 m.
At low altitude less snow than usual is lying.
